that's fine. you have two new kernels when you upgraded, so they were added to grub's menu.lst

each time a new kernel is installed, a new entry will be made in that list. if you don't want the old ones in there, you can remove them, but be very careful and be sure to back up your /boot/grub/menu.1st first.
i would leave what you have there alone. that's not a long list. on my current (Debian) machine i have about 15 kernels.
yes all you need to do is delete the lines. remember that for each new kernel added, there is a 'recovery' entry added. you only really have 2 kernels there! that's fine. leave it.
